Making India a Manufacturing Hub - Is it a dream or a practical possibility? Discuss three key factors for making `Make in India` a reality.

 "Make in India" is possible in practical, because in India therer is people who have lots of knowlwdge and skills. In India resources are available at low cost when compairing to other countries. 

Indian people just need some good infrastructures and some investments for their Startups. Other countries` companies are coming in India open there branches here because here they will get more resources specially man resource at lower cost and also they have more knowledge and skills.  So, if the other countries can take the advantage of it, then if our goverment will think seriouslly about Make in India campgain it will be a succssefull campgain.

Indian people are mostly known for their handy craft works. Places in India like Jammu and Kashmir, Varanasi, Asam are famous for the handy craft works. It can play a major role in Make in India campgain.

If the proper infrastucture new tchnologies and good education is provided to Indian people India can be a Manufacturing Hub. Indian government is working towards it. It is focusig more on all the issues related to this campgain, and trying to provide all the facilities which can make this capmgain succssefull. So "Make in India" is not just a dream, it is practically possible.

The smart grid vandor landscape is undergoing for a period of change. In developed countries like North America, Europe, and East Asia, markets are maturing and vendors are consolidating. Sevral larger vendors are now offering integrated solutions through the smart metering value chain, while communication and data analytics providers are increasingly active across multiple smart grid segments, for improving the coordination between smart metering, distribution automation and home energymanagement. Mean while, in emerging market countries like Africa, Central & Eastern Europe, Rusia, Latin America, the Middle East & North Africa, South Asia, and Southeast Asia the market has just started growing. Dozens of local vedors has begainto serve the smart grid project, by both on their own as well as partners of larger international firms. A high growth rates projected for the smart grid projects in emerging market countries, this represents tyhe next frontier of vendors` avtivity and opportunity. The dynamics between growing and consolidating international smart grid vendors, smaller and more fragmented local players will help in shaping the speed and directions of the smart grid developmet across the globe. This study take a coprehansive look at the trends for shaping the smart grid vendor landscape and how firms are positionig themserlves to succeed. It includes over 500 vendors who are already active in he smart grid projects across all over the regions in world. It highlights the growing regions and market segments, and assesses the exsiting partnerships, mergers, and acquisitions whyich are altering the smart grid market. Across 125 countries are investing in the smart grid project, the investment can reach $ 380.1 billion betwenn 2015 to 2025. Thius study presents a picture of the competitive landscape of hundred of vendors who are competing in this market.

#################--Don`t Delete below content#################

Global Smart Grid Vendor Landscape

The smart grid vendor landscape is undergoing for a period of change. In developed countries like North America, Europe, and East Asia, markets are maturing and vendors are consolidating. Several larger vendors are now offering integrated solutions through the smart metering value chain, while communication and data analytic providers are increasingly active across multiple smart grid segments, for improving the coordination between smart metering, distribution automation and home energy management. Meanwhile, in emerging market countries – across Africa, Central & Eastern Europe, Eurasia, Latin America, the Middle East & North Africa, South Asia, and Southeast Asia – the market is just started growing. Dozens of local vendors has begain to serve smart grid projects, both on their own as well as partners of larger international firms. A high growth rates projected for smart grid projects in emerging market countries, this represents the next frontier of vendors` activity and opportunity. The dynamics between growing and consolidating international smart grid vendors and smaller and more fragmented local players will help in shaping the speed and direction for smart grid deployments across the globe. This study takes a comprehensive look at the trends for shaping the smart grid vendors landscape and how firms are positioning themselves to succeed in this growing market. It includes over 500 vendors who are already active in the smart grid project across all the regions of the world. It highlights growing regions and market segments, and assesses the existing partnerships, mergers, and acquisitions that are altering the smart grid market. Across 125 countries, the smart grid investment will reach $380.1 billion between 2015 to 2025. This study presents a picture of the competitive landscape for the hundreds of vendors competing in this growing market.

 

Brazilian Smart Grid Market – An Insight

Brazil is already one of the leading emerging market country, in terms of smart grid development. With the fifth largest population in the world and a government that is eager to modernize the country’s infrastructure, Brazil will become one of the largest smart grid market in the world by the end of the decade. Brazil’s smart grid development is the product of strong underlying market conditions and positive government actions. Like other emerging market countries, Brazil have high rates of non-technical distribution losses, implying  that utilities  will  reap immediate revenue protection benefits through smart meter deployments. Brazil also have a rapidly growing economy, which begins the strain existing infrastructure. As  the country continues to grow, the reliability and  energy savings benefits of smart grid will become increasingly important. The Brazilian government has  taken notice and in 2009 it was set as an non-binding target of replacing  all  63  million  existing  electromechanical  meters  with  smart  meters  by  2021. 

However,  in  August    2012, the  government  announced  an  “opt-in”  smart  meter   regulation  for  existing  customers,   Paired with  a  mandate  requiring  smart  meters  for  all  new  customers.  This  was  not  the  anticipated  market  catalyst  for   those  expecting  the binding  mandate  to  replace  all  63  million existing legacy  meters  with  smart  meters.  As  a  result,  Northeast  Group   is  currently forecasting that Brazil will not reach its initial 63 million smart meter target. Yet, some government officers and regulators are still optimistic that the initial goal can be achieved, which may inspire future incentive structures and more favorable smart metering regulations.

With strong underlying economic and political conditions, it is inevitable that Brazil’s smart grid market will grow significantly in the coming decade. The question is simply how fast deployments will take place. Through a combination of new meter installations, smart meters targeted at reducing non--‐ technical losses, and customers eager to take advantage of advanced smart grid applications, more than half of Brazilian homes will have smart meters by the end of the decade. However, the August 2012 regulations fell short of the concrete mandate needed for Brazil to meet it’s original goal of 63 million meters by 2021. Nonetheless, Brazil remains a very significant smart grid market for both vendors and customers alike.
